metadata.case_name: Alapati Venkataramaiah v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: The assessee, Alapati Venkataramaiah, was the proprietor of Mohan Tile Works at Tenali, engaged in manufacture of tiles and bricks, owning factory buildings, plant and machinery.
Mohan Industries Limited was incorporated on July 5, 1947.
Assessee entered into agreement dated March 17, 1948 with Shri Manthena Venkata Raju to sell factory, plant, machinery, furniture, stocks and goodwill to the Company for Rs. 2,00,000.

Agreement recited business carried on under name Mohan Tile Works; Company to be formed under Indian Companies Act for acquisition and working of the business; relevant clauses specified sale of goodwill, immovable properties per Schedule, plant/machinery/furniture etc. per Second Schedule, materials per Third Schedule; consideration Rs. 2,00,000 payable after capital Rs. 3,00,000 raised; completion by March 17, 1948 with possession; interest if delayed; adoption by Company to discharge Manthena; either party could terminate before Company entitled to commence business.
Assessee appointed managing agents of Company on July 15, 1947.
On March 11, 1948, assessee as managing agents wrote to Director of Industries and Commerce, Madras, furnishing list of land, building, machinery comprising assets with values for loan.
Possession of premises given to Company on March 17, 1948 as far as practicable.

On March 20, 1948, assessee credited with Rs. 2,00,000 in Company books; corresponding entries in assessee's books debiting Company and crediting assets: Plant Machinery Rs.15,989; Furniture Rs.18,805; Electric goods Rs.1,289/10; Site Construction Rs.1,26,470; Stock Rs.30,050; Goodwill Rs.7,396/6.
Sale deed for land executed in favour of Company on November 22, 1948 for Rs.4,500.
On December 9, 1948, Company mortgaged land, buildings, structures, machinery, plant for Rs.1,00,000 to State of Madras.
Board of Directors by resolution No.22 on March 16, 1949 approved agreement dated March 17, 1948.
Agreement approved at annual general meeting on April 10, 1949.
First annual report dated March 22, 1949 stated Company registered July 5, 1947; entered vendors agreement with assessee on 17-3-1948.
Assessment year 1948-49, accounting year official year 1947-48.
Assessee returned income as capital gains; ITO held excess Rs.79,494 over original cost as capital gains under s.12B.
Assessee appealed to AAC claiming building sold at Rs.1,69,950 but only Rs.1 lakh received, balance pending; transaction incomplete, no profits realised.
AAC upheld: part payment irrelevant; no substance in no legal transfer as Company got loan as owners.
Tribunal order Nov 24, 1955: no sale or legal transfer, only agreement to sell; no receipt in year; deleted addition despite return.

CIT applied under s.35 for rectification; Tribunal rectified March 8, 1957: possession handed March 17, 1948 per cl.6; book entries March 20; sale deed only land; relied on letter March 11, annual report.

High Court answered question affirmatively: transfer by possession; s.12B words sale/transfer; right to receive; movables/immovables transferred by possession, title perfected later; accounting showed income arisen.
Statement of case agreed: agreement approved by Board resolution on 26.3.1949, agreed to pay in instalments from 31.3.1949; approved general body 10.4.1949.
Assessee received Rs.1 lakh in instalments from 25-3-1949.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case a sum of Rs. 79,494/- is assessable as capital gains in the assessment year 1948-49.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under s.12B, profits deemed income of year in which sale, exchange or transfer took place; sale when Board ratified agreement March 16/26, 1949; till then only agreement to sell, not sale or transfer; conditional agreement requiring adoption by Company (cl.8,9); no sale/transfer before April 1, 1948.
Title to immovable property (site/buildings Rs.1,26,470; plant/machinery Rs.15,989) passes only by registered conveyance, executed Nov 22, 1948.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Bhurangya Coal Co.

petitioner_arguments.text: Delivery of possession not equivalent to conveyance/transfer under s.12B; entries in books irrelevant for date of transfer.
Distinction between movables/immovables; stocks Rs.30,050 not capital asset.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Income Tax Act, 1922 definition of capital asset

respondent_arguments.text: Transfer by putting Company in possession March 17, 1948; s.53A TPA prevents repossession; entries March 20 show receipt; right to receive under agreement immediately, treated as received.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Income Tax Act, 1922 s.12B; Transfer of Property Act s.53A

respondent_arguments.text: s.12B uses 'sale, exchange, relinquishment or transfer'; transfer wider than sale, not requiring registered instrument; immaterial when money paid if transfer made.
Cl.8,9 only if agreement pre-incorporation; discard them; entire property transferred by possession, title perfected by conveyance later; accounting shows income in year.

court_reasoning.text: Agreement dated March 17, 1948 is conditional agreement to sell, requiring adoption by Company to bind it (cl.8,9); cannot discard clauses; adopted by Board 26.3.1949 and general body 10.4.1949 per statement of case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agreement did not ripen into contract till 1949.

court_reasoning.text: Even if agreement accepted earlier, no sale/transfer of immovables before April 1, 1948: title passes by registered conveyance (site deed Nov 22, 1948); plant/machinery embedded immovable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No conveyance before April 1, 1948 for buildings/site Rs.1,26,470, machinery Rs.15,989, electrical Rs.1,289.

court_reasoning.text: Transfer under s.12B requires effective conveyance; possession/delivery alone not sufficient for immovables; book entries irrelevant for date.
Stocks Rs.30,050 expressly not capital asset.
Furniture Rs.18,805: title passes by delivery with intention, on March 17, 1948.
Goodwill Rs.7,396: intangible, passes with whole business, not transferred before April 1, 1948.

holdings.text: No sale or transfer of machinery Rs.15,989, electrical fittings Rs.1,289, buildings/site Rs.1,26,470 before April 1, 1948; stocks not capital asset; furniture transferred; goodwill not.
Rs.79,494 not assessable as capital gains in 1948-49 except part attributable to furniture Rs.18,805.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Bhurangya Coal Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Title to immovable property passes by registered conveyance.

statutes_cited.name: Income Tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Capital gains on sale/exchange/transfer of capital asset after March 31, 1946 before April 1, 1948 deemed income of previous year; reference; rectification.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Part performance; possession with contract prevents repossession, but not sufficient for transfer under s.12B.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Company formation and adoption of agreement.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court answered the question referred negatively: the sum of Rs. 79,494/- is not assessable as capital gains in 1948-49, except such part as attributable to capital gain from transfer of furniture valued at Rs. 18,805/- which is assessable.
outcome.relief_granted: Capital gains assessment limited to furniture portion only.

key_quotes.text: "In the facts and circumstances of the case the sum of Rs. 79,494/- is not assessable as capital gains in the assessment year 1948-49, but only such part of it, if any, as is attributable to the capital gain made by the transfer of furniture valued at Rs. 18,805/- is assessable."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Final answer to the referred question.

key_quotes.text: Delivery of possession of immovable property cannot by itself be treated as equivalent to conveyance of the immovable property.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects possession as transfer under s.12B.

key_quotes.text: It seems to us that it was a conditional agreement to sell and before it could ripen into a contract between the company and the assessee, it had to be adopted by the company.
key_quotes.speaker: court
